Introduction

Hydrocephalus is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricles of the brain, leading to increased intracranial pressure (ICP) and ventricular dilation.  In children, hydrocephalus may be congenital or acquired, and it can present at any age from infancy to adolescence.  Clinical manifestations vary with age and chronicity, and untreated hydrocephalus can lead to brain injury with long-term neurologic sequelae.

Pathogenesis



Most of the CSF is produced by the choroid plexus, a highly vascular tissue within the cerebral ventricles that is formed by fenestrated capillary outgrowths covered by modified ependymal cells.  CSF circulates throughout the ventricular system before passing to the subarachnoid space to be reabsorbed (

figure 1
):



  • CSF formed in the lateral ventricles exits through the corresponding interventricular foramina of Monro into the third ventricle.
  • From the third ventricle, it flows through the aqueduct of Sylvius to reach the fourth ventricle.
  • CSF exits the fourth ventricle through either one of the paired lateral foramina of Luschka or the medial foramen of Magendie to reach the subarachnoid space.
  • CSF is then reabsorbed by the arachnoid villi into the venous circulation (
    figure 2
    ).


Hydrocephalus results from the disruption of this process and is traditionally classified as one of two types:



  • Noncommunicating (obstructive) hydrocephalus:  A structural blockage, usually within the ventriculi, prevents CSF flow (eg, aqueductal stenosis, tumors).  Ventriculi above the obstruction are enlarged, whereas those below the obstruction are normal.
  • Communicating hydrocephalus:  Communicating hydrocephalus usually occurs secondary to dysfunction or obliteration of subarachnoid villi; CSF can still flow through the ventricular system, but absorption is impaired (eg, postmeningitis scarring, intraventricular hemorrhage).  Rarely, increased CSF production can also cause a communicating hydrocephalus, usually due to choroid plexus papilloma.  In communicating hydrocephalus, all ventriculi are symmetrically enlarged.


Prolonged ventricular dilation increases ICP, compresses brain parenchyma, and may result in cortical thinning and axonal injury.

Risk factors



Hydrocephalus in children may result from either congenital anomalies or acquired conditions.

Congenital causes



  • Neural tube defects:  Myelomeningocele is the most common cause of congenital hydrocephalus.
  • Congenital malformations:  Aqueductal stenosis (eg, narrowing of the cerebral aqueduct) and Chiari II malformation (eg, herniation of cerebellar structures).
  • Congenital infections [eg, TORCH (toxoplasmosis, other infections, rubella, cytomegalovirus infection, and herpes simplex)].
  • Genetic syndromes (eg, X-linked hydrocephalus).

Acquired causes



  • Intraventricular hemorrhage, especially in premature infants.
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage.
  • CNS infections (eg, bacterial meningitis).
  • Brain tumors that obstruct CSF flow (eg, medulloblastoma, ependymoma).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of hydrocephalus varies based on patient age and the rate at which ventricular enlargement occurs.



In infants, the open sutures and fontanelles give space for the skull to expand, allowing for volume expansion with a smaller increase in pressure.  The earliest sign is often a rapidly enlarging head circumference, with or without macrocephaly (circumference >97th percentile).  Nonspecific findings can include irritability, poor feeding, and/or developmental delay.  Examination may show a full or bulging fontanelle, widely spaced cranial sutures, prominent scallop veins, or persistent downward/upward gaze impairment (due to pressure on the midbrain).



Ventricular enlargement cannot be accommodated by skull expansion in older children, whose cranial sutures have closed (typically after 12-15 months); therefore, they are more likely to present with signs/symptoms of increased ICP.  This may include classic features of headache (that is worse in the morning), nausea/vomiting, and papilledema.  As the pressure increases, muscle spasticity and hyperreflexia due to stretching of the periventricular pyramidal tracts may occur.



The rate of progression also influences the presenting features.  Rapidly progressive hydrocephalus may present acutely with lethargy, cranial nerve palsies, or seizures, reflecting abrupt increases in ICP.  In contrast, gradual ventricular enlargement may lead to more subtle signs such as behavioral changes, poor school performance, gait instability, or developmental delay.

Diagnosis



The first step in evaluation of suspected hydrocephalus is neuroimaging.  In an infant with an open fontanelle, ultrasonography of the head may be performed to avoid radiation exposure and confirm the presence of enlarged ventricles.  MRI of the brain is used in older children and better visualizes the structures of the brain, particularly the posterior fossa; sometimes, ultrafast MRI can be used to avoid sedation.  Because of radiation exposure, CT scan is typically reserved for patients with acute signs of rising ICP.



In cases with concern for meningitis, lumbar puncture may be performed for CSF analysis if imaging excludes elevated ICP/herniation risk.  Genetic testing may be performed in suspected syndromic or familial cases.

Differential diagnosis



  • Benign extraaxial fluid of infancy:  This is a common cause of benign macrocephaly; infants typically have normal development without any signs of increased ICP.  Head imaging will typically show enlarged subarachnoid spaces in the frontal areas rather than hydrocephalus.
  • Reduced brain volume (eg, hydrocephalus ex vacuo):  In patients with cerebral volume loss due to prior injury or malformation, imaging may show increased prominence of the sulci consistent with cortical atrophy.  The compensatory increased CSF volume is due to a significant loss of neuronal volume rather than impaired CSF flow.
  • Normal pressure hydrocephalus:  This is rare in children and is typically present only in older adults.  Classically, patients present with the triad of gait disturbance, dementia, and urinary incontinence.  Imaging will show ventricular enlargement.
  • Pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension):  This condition typically occurs in young adults rather than children.  Patients present with signs of elevated ICP (eg, headache, papilledema, visual changes) without ventricular enlargement on imaging.  CSF opening pressure is elevated, and neuroimaging is normal or shows slit-like ventricles.

Management



Management depends on the etiology and severity of symptoms.  The goal is to divert CSF, relieve pressure, and treat underlying causes.  Medical therapy (eg, acetazolamide, furosemide) has limited utility and is used only in select cases or as a temporizing measure.  Surgical interventions are the mainstay of treatment and include:



  • Ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt:  This is the most common surgical intervention used for long-term management of hydrocephalus.  A VP shunt is a mechanical device placed for obstructive hydrocephalus to prevent excessive CSF accumulation by redirecting CSF for absorption outside the CNS (ie, peritoneum) (
    figure 3
    ).
  • Endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV):  This procedure is typically used for noncommunicating hydrocephalus.  In ETV, an endoscopic opening in the floor of the third ventricle is created to bypass obstruction.


Postoperative care includes monitoring for:



  • Shunt malfunction:  Tubing may migrate, split, or kink, thereby obstructing drainage and causing recurrence of hydrocephalus and a life-threatening increase in ICP (eg, ischemia, herniation).  Symptoms of increased ICP (eg, headache, vomiting, papilledema) usually occur.
  • Infection:  May cause fever, shunt tenderness, and neurologic decline.  Abdominal pain may occur if peritonitis develops due to distal shunt infection.
  • Overdrainage:  Can lead to slit ventricles and subdural hematomas.


Work-up for postoperative complications focuses primarily on evaluating the patient's neurologic status (eg, neurologic examination, funduscopy), the integrity of the shunt (eg, head imaging with CT, ultrasonography or shunt-series x-rays), and the possibility of infection (eg, complete blood count, blood cultures, shunt tap).  Shunt complications can occur at any time after placement but usually occur within the first 6 months (and most commonly within the first month).

Prognosis



Prognosis varies depending on etiology, timing of intervention, and the presence of comorbid conditions.  With timely management, many children with hydrocephalus achieve developmental milestones.  However, delays in diagnosis or recurrent shunt complications can result in cognitive impairment, motor deficits, and vision problems.  Long-term follow-up is often required.

Summary



Pediatric hydrocephalus is a condition characterized by cerebrospinal fluid accumulation within the ventricles due to impaired flow or absorption.  Presentation varies with age but may include macrocephaly, vomiting, headache, and developmental delay.  Diagnosis is confirmed with neuroimaging.  Management typically involves surgical diversion of cerebrospinal fluid via a ventriculoperitoneal shunt.  Early recognition and intervention are essential to reduce neurologic morbidity and optimize developmental outcomes.
